title: Mastering Camera Talk for Better Headshots
summary: Peter Hurley explains the concept of 'Camera Talk,' detailing the optimal physical positioning for a photographer during a session. He distinguishes between stepping away from the camera for coaching and teaching concepts versus staying locked behind the lens to elicit and capture immediate reactions.

steps.action: Execute the standard headshot system: position the body, position the head, and scan hair and clothing.
Step away from the camera for initial coaching to make eye contact and reduce intimidation.
Lock in behind the camera once the shot is composed to begin 'Camera Talk'.
Issue directions from behind the lens to provoke a reaction and capture the image immediately.
Move away from the camera again when teaching specific techniques (like the squinch or jawline moves) that require the subject to mirror you.
Return to the viewfinder to establish a shooting rhythm: give a command, wait for the reaction, and fire instantly.

key_takeaways: Use 'Camera Talk' (staying behind the viewfinder) when you need to capture split-second reactions.
Step away from the camera when teaching concepts or establishing rapport to avoid hiding behind the gear.
You may need to speak louder when engaging in Camera Talk because the camera body blocks your voice.
The goal is to keep the subject engaged with the lens during the shooting phase.
